title: 110_hr3133
content: The Act may be cited as the "Financial Literacy for Homeowners Act". The Congress acknowledges that while expanded access to credit has increased homeownership rates, there is evidence of predatory lending practices that make it costly for low-income families. Borrowers with fair to good credit can access loans in the prime mortgage market with the lowest rates and costs. Predatory lending in the subprime mortgage market involves high interest rates, excessive fees, balloon payments, and other unreasonable terms. Predatory loans in minority neighborhoods strip away wealth accumulated over decades, victimizing communities with high-interest home equity loans and inadequate disclosures. The joint report by the Department of Housing and Urban Development and the Department of the Treasury urged Congress to adopt legislation to restrict abusive terms on high-cost loans and improve consumer disclosures. The joint report recommended legislation to address predatory lending practices, including improving consumer literacy and disclosures by requiring lenders to provide home mortgage counseling, disclose credit scores, and give timely and accurate loan information. Government agencies are addressing predatory lending to reduce high-pressure sales techniques and misleading borrowers about loan terms. Nonprofit organizations are at risk due to predatory lending, and more assistance is needed for borrowers with predatory loans. To address predatory lending, efforts are being made to assist borrowers with existing predatory loans, educate consumers about the risks of home loans, and provide referrals to government agencies or consumer protection organizations for help. The grant program aims to provide education and counseling on predatory lending. The Secretary of the Treasury may grant funds to States, local governments, and nonprofits for eligible anti-predatory lending activities, including education programs for vulnerable consumers. The curr_chunk discusses predatory lending practices in relation to home loans, including high interest rates, excessive fees, and fraudulent terms. It also mentions counseling programs for homeowners to educate them on these practices. Referral services for homeowners and prospective homeowners to education, counseling programs, and appropriate agencies handling consumer complaints regarding predatory lending practices related to home loans. The section outlines the eligibility and application process for grants related to home loans, requiring submission of an application with specific information. The maximum grant amount for a single grantee in a fiscal year is set at $1,000,000. The Secretary will select applicants for grants based on established criteria, with a maximum grant amount of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. SEC. 4. TOLL-FREE TELEPHONE NUMBER FOR PREDATORY LENDING COMPLAINTS. The Secretary will establish a toll-free telephone number for consumer complaints about predatory lending practices related to home loans. The number will provide information, refer borrowers with predatory loans to appropriate agencies, and coordinate with State and nonprofit organizations to create a resource database for consumers. The telephone line for consumer complaints about predatory lending practices related to home loans must be staffed by a live person at all times, not by pre-recorded messages. SEC. 5. PREDATORY LENDING ADVISORY COUNCIL. Established in the Department of the Treasury, the Predatory Lending Advisory Council advises the Secretary on issues related to predatory lending practices for home loans. The Council consists of 13 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from community-based organizations working to improve distressed neighborhoods and assist borrowers with predatory loans. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council advises the Secretary on predatory lending practices for home loans. It consists of 13 members, including borrowers with predatory loans, state officials, private homeowners familiar with mortgages, and representatives from the real estate industry. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council consists of 13 members from various backgrounds, including borrowers with predatory loans, state officials, private homeowners, and representatives from the real estate industry. Council members serve two-year terms, with initial members serving staggered terms. They receive travel expenses but no compensation, and the Secretary designates a chairperson. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council meets at least three times a year and has the authority to hold public hearings and receive testimony. It provides advice to the Secretary on the grant program and criteria for selecting grant recipients. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council oversees grant amounts, operates a toll-free telephone number, coordinates with lending institutions on preventing predatory lending practices, and conducts studies on default and foreclosure causes. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council conducts an extensive study on the root causes of default and foreclosure of home loans, using empirical data. They will submit a report with recommendations for consumer protection legislation within 12 months of the Council's full membership appointment. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The term "home loan" under this Act refers to a loan made to a natural person, secured by a deed on residential property or a manufactured home, including renewals or refinancing. It includes home equity lines of credit and home improvement loans. The term "predatory or unscrupulous lending practice" includes making loans solely based on the borrower's home equity. The term "predatory or unscrupulous lending practice" includes making unaffordable loans without considering the borrower's ability to repay, inducing borrowers to refinance loans. The term "predatory or unscrupulous lending practice" includes inducing a borrower to refinance a loan repeatedly and charging additional points and fees, as well as engaging in fraud or deception to conceal the true nature of the loan obligation from an unsuspecting or unsophisticated borrower. The term "unit of general local government" refers to any city, town, township, parish, village, or other political subdivision of a State. SEC. 7. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. $55,000,000 authorized for fiscal years 2008-2012. Not more than $2,000,000 for section 4 and not more than $5,000,000 for section 5. SEC. 8. REGULATIONS. Secretary may issue necessary regulations for Act.
